document.title: Maryland College and Career Ready Standards for English Language Arts Grades 3-5

2A4EBAEF074C4C3C9D138EB297BC391F.description:
Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain
specific words and phrases, including those
that signal precise actions, emotions, or states
of being (e.g., quizzed, whined, stammered)
and that are basic to a particular topic (e.g.,
wildlife, conservation, and endangered when
discussing animal preservation).

CC5E7BDA0A0B4648B00B3378B3B7D2B7.description:
Demonstrate understanding of
words by relating them to their opposites
(antonyms) and to words with similar but
not identical meanings (synonyms).

585E78B23F7345F9BF33459B2D2A8002.description:
Recognize and explain the
meaning of common idioms, adages, and
proverbs.

7F69280C116247A5AE29A64EAEEBB469.description:
Explain the meaning of simple
similes and metaphors(e.g., as pretty as a
picture) in context.

FC6F7128BFC74A2DA548339C976E53EB.description:
Demonstrate understanding of figurative
language, word relationships, and nuances in
word meanings.

B1697DF90CFA41B7B42D7CAB5D17085D.description:
Consult reference materials (e.g.,
dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both
print and digital, to find the pronunciation
and determine or clarify the precise
meaning of key words and phrases.

577E79CDB4CB4CD0AC71E6B6A9C04230.description:
Use common, grade appropriate
Greek and Latin affixes and roots as clues
to the meaning of a word (e.g., telegraph,
photograph, autograph).

9FAA6840C9354B91945EB943ACAD9F46.description:
Use context (e.g., definitions,
examples, or restatements in text) as a
clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

0D5F46978892487C9D83073631EDAEA7.description:
Determine or clarify the meaning of
unknown and multiple-meaning words and
phrases based on grade 4 reading and content,
choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

C2B85A8AB47940A2995D0C1710294F56.description:
Differentiate between contexts
that call for formal English (e.g.,
presenting ideas) and situations where
informal discourse is appropriate (e.g.,
small-group discussion).

FF5BC20DB4A34957A4CD4F10AC096F80.description:
Choose words and phrases to
convey ideas precisely. *

813A4DD2A7044CDFB3D53967820D98ED.description:
Use knowledge of language and its
conventions when writing, speaking, reading,
or listening.

1D7A9AB5378149AD8B19572A31170DBD.description:
Spell grade-appropriate words
correctly, consulting references as
needed.

19782D62325B4FE9A7751BE3D1AF685B.description:
Use a comma before a
coordinating conjunction in a compound
sentence.

2F2CD8B5232C4BF5B90A3EB62D6B1D9A.description:
Use commas and quotation marks
to mark direct speech and quotations
from a text.

EA7F4131DD4848CBB555AB063CC4C8E1.description:
Demonstrate command of the
conventions of standard English capitalization,
punctuation, and spelling when writing.

F1C1C29F7DEB4537AFC27B0D0A742B77.description:
Correctly use frequently confused
words (e.g., to, too, two; there, their).*

19D7AB2C2F6B4AD6AD46F28BB53CFC93.description:
Produce complete sentences,
recognizing and correcting inappropriate
fragments and run-ons. *

B51798375C17465C8F80F4ABAFB75FE2.description:
Order adjectives within sentences
according to conventional patterns(e.g., a
small red bag rather than a red small
bag).

DE57098421DE4829847FA6B42F932548.description:
Use modal auxiliaries (e.g., can,
may, must) to convey various conditions.

2EA5BAF0C710442E8D22A2960C93DA93.description:
Form and use the progressive
(e.g., I was walking; I am walking; I will be
walking) verb tenses.

ABAB1DAFCB774AEFA374B454DB4C8389.description:
Use relative pronouns (who,
whose, whom, which, that) and relative
adverbs (where, when, why).

C209DC2731D645CA825FF8E16A593838.description:
Demonstrate command of the
conventions of standard English grammar
and usage when writing or speaking.

79F53E8469D543D484587D69BA22558A.description:
Differentiate between contexts that call
for formal English (e.g., presenting ideas) and
situations where informal discourse is
appropriate (e.g., small-group discussion); use
formal English when appropriate to task and
situation. (See grade 4 Language standards 1
for specific expectations.)

DA340709969D4F0B8299448F0E04D7A6.description:
Add audio recordings and visual displays
to presentations when appropriate to enhance
the development of main ideas or themes.

0CAB7A6241A44331AEB9520A94F0D9B0.description:
Report on a topic or text, tell a story, or
recount an experience in an organized manner,
using appropriate facts and relevant,
descriptive details to support main ideas or
themes; speak clearly at an understandable
pace.

30DF9972FF6B4AE0AF24311521263CE1.description:
Identify the reasons and evidence a
speaker provides to support particular points.

583D3D6B4E934B389E51B77F683E2E5E.description:
Paraphrase portions of a text read aloud
or information presented in diverse media and
formats, including visually, quantitatively, and
orally.

ACF5A88738BD439094B85DE638BE9595.description:
Review the key ideas expressed
and explain their own ideas and
understanding in light of the discussion.

ACA66564FCA04B12995E6937DD8BDB1A.description:
Pose and respond to specific questions to clarify or follow up
on information, and make comments that
contribute to the discussion and link to
the remarks of others.

8A4B8CB6E5D04F3FACE7FBECAFA4E2EA.description:
Follow agreed-upon rules for
discussions and carry out assigned roles.

BA4CC47CCCA64356AD157CD6AC990D7C.description:
Come to discussions prepared,
having read or studied required material;
explicitly draw on that preparation and
other information known about the topic
to explore ideas under discussion.

23F742D471EA4A8493422BC28099B5AA.description:
Engage effectively in a range of
collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in
groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners
on grade 4 topics and texts, building on others'
ideas and expressing their own clearly.

235017B88BF04BE783ACEACFBD632A51.description:
Write routinely over extended time
frames (time for research, reflection, and
revision) and shorter time frames (a single
sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.

43EB71992CB34730BC71EB7B9644DB1D.description:
Apply grade 4 Reading standards
to informational texts (e.g., "Explain how
an author uses reasons and evidence to
support particular points in a text").

4E811A7233A94797A1DE5BE418DBEB54.description:
Apply grade 4 Reading standards
to literature (e.g., "Describe in depth a
character, setting, or event in a story or
drama, drawing on specific details in the
text [e.g., a character's thoughts, words,
or actions].").

3AA3BD1849FC463A845E17700A0E0D84.description:
Draw evidence from literary or
informational texts to support analysis,
reflection, and research.

CDD61C6B7CDD41EDA1EA53B34CB77CE8.description:
Recall relevant information from
experiences or gather relevant information
from print and digital sources; take notes and
categorize information, and provide a list of
sources.

B28C172491054D96BC4C4C431669E736.description:
Conduct short research projects that
build knowledge through investigation of
different aspects of a topic.

5229848E57D641F2BC7645E68EBDABC3.description: Research to Build and Present Knowledge

D09C04A5C3ED4F478E6BFAB8A3070E77.description:
With some guidance and support from
adults, use technology, including the Internet,
to produce and publish writing as well as to
interact and collaborate with others;
demonstrate sufficient command of
keyboarding skills to type a minimum of one
page in a single sitting.

52396D408F03409EB911ABE5649FF76D.description:
With guidance and support from peers
and adults, develop and strengthen writing as
needed by planning, revising, and editing.
(Editing for conventions should demonstrate
command of Language standards 1-3 up to and
including grade 4.)

6BC7D84DCC0645ADBD5391E1D9065D37.description:
Produce clear and coherent writing in
which the development and organization are
appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.
(Grade-specific expectations for writing types
are defined in standards 1-3 above.)

CAA3D2DC82BE4174BF404B2C0233851E.description:
Provide a conclusion that follows
from the narrated experiences or events.

D516383ACC774D7A84927DAFCC50641C.description:
Use concrete words and phrases
and sensory details to convey experiences
and events precisely.

9DBA715B7FA7495AAB357637A29525EB.description:
Use a variety of transitional
words and phrases to manage the
sequence of events.

2AF07CDF67984D27B10A958758F8496D.description:
Use dialogue and description to
develop experiences and events or show
the responses of charactersto situations.

5AAA06DE73DD4ED9B2D1D048E702A505.description:
Orient the reader by establishing
a situation and introducing a narrator
and/or characters; organize an event
sequence that unfolds naturally.

86B0DDDFF6364B78B54062AEDDBAD10E.description:
Write narratives to develop real or
imagined experiences or events using effective
technique, descriptive details, and clear event
sequences.

909C6FAE46A24BE3B8D75E6D05E87008.description:
Provide a concluding statement
or section related to the information or
explanation presented.

E483F0351A27492AB8561A1DC031B57D.description:
Use precise language and
domain-specific vocabulary to inform
about or explain the topic.

979046FC870E49A491AF8C9FCB477DA7.description:
Link ideas within categories of
information using words and phrases
(e.g., another, for example, also, because).

95E1D5D6AE634248A9F787B7006ADFBD.description:
Develop the topic with facts,
definitions, concrete details, quotations,
or other information and examples
related to the topic.

F3D003F6EA714000A59668F3051A72EF.description:
Introduce a topic clearly and
group related information in paragraphs
and sections; include formatting (e.g.,
headings), illustrations, and multimedia
when useful to aiding comprehension.

24F9256EA3C34BABAEEFA6A7950B2636.description:
Write informative/explanatory texts to
examine a topic and convey ideas and
information clearly.

E19ED46812F3453CBB86AB548B55D44D.description:
Provide a concluding statement
or section related to the opinion
presented.

D568D9F961034E2EA3F2FD6395722E0C.description:
Link opinion and reasons using
words and phrases(e.g., for instance, in
order to, in addition).

BEC9D4DD44184E0CBA233459A34CBD69.description:
Provide reasons that are
supported by facts and details.

0A8E4F883E1641EDBC141CCD7A8615E8.description:
Introduce a topic or text clearly,
state an opinion, and create an
organizational structure in which related
ideas are grouped to support the writer's
purpose.

686561384FDD485CB4D05BB3CEF6A51A.description:
Write opinion pieces on topics or texts,
supporting a point of view with reasons and
information.

E1632CBE529F4613B547F9B00422FF25.description:
Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and
understanding, rereading as necessary.

AAC4B21B8E7E48A9A4EEF268FA2AAD9F.description:
Read grade-level prose and
poetry orally with accuracy, appropriate
rate, and expression on successive
readings.

50534956C5FC4FB58BBD6BFBC78A7BE4.description:
Read grade-level text with
purpose and understanding.

73873B4DAFE04D8FB54EEEF3E665430F.description:
Read with sufficient accuracy and
fluency to support comprehension.

C133633D39B9489D93626C58773171F3.description:
Use combined knowledge of all
letter-sound correspondences,
syllabication patterns, and morphology
(e.g., roots and affixes) to read accurately
unfamiliar multisyllabic words in context
and out of context.

57E0C715A925493C9F5DDB014BA31411.description:
Know and apply grade-level phonics and
word analysis skills in decoding words.

2D157AD6BC0D4642B26B2755217AB5E1.description:
By the end of year, read and
comprehend informational texts, including
history/social studies, science, and technical
texts, in the grades 4-5 text complexity band
proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the
high end of the range.

B671AD33AE084CF9892980211E62AB35.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

2CACA61680DA40C78092829FA3DD12EC.description:
Integrate information from two texts on
the same topic in order to write or speak about
the subject knowledgeably.

E6E76FC8A96D497D95170606EE64F8AB.description:
Explain how an author uses reasons and
evidence to support particular points in a text.

7661A493D08D4D709977833552A4A98D.description:
Interpret information presented visually,
orally, or quantitatively (e.g., in charts, graphs,
diagrams, time lines, Web pages) and explain
how the information contributes to an
understanding of the text in which it appears.

39B5F1CE85C94536AF602E0655227914.description:
Compare and contrast a firsthand and
secondhand account of the same event or
topic; describe the differences in focus and the
information provided.

12C7F7641BFA4DA5B995B56C99558919.description:
Describe the overall structure (e.g.,
chronology, comparison, cause/effect,
problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts,
or information in a text or part of a text.

0B14AE64C65A4F6BAE5D96569466DD5D.description:
Determine the meaning of general
academic and domain-specific words or
phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or
subject area.

80EF1099135A4FB2903824614939CE22.description:
Explain events, procedures, ideas, or
concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical
text, including what happened and why, based
on specific information in the text.

15D0E37ECD6047FB9C1F458B0BF20B48.description:
Refer to details and examples in a text
when explaining what the text says explicitly
and when drawing inferences from the text.

5D069C40383F4720A9137929202E68C6.description:
By the end of the year, read and
comprehend literature, including stories,
dramas, and poetry, in the grades 4-5 text
complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding
as needed at the high end of the range.

B8FD449E4D6641FC93BEB3D853E65E36.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

389458977FE3466C85E06C5080B5B6DF.description:
Compare and contrast the treatment of
similar themes and topics (e.g., opposition of
good and evil) and patterns of events(e.g., the
quest) in stories, myths, and traditional
literature from different cultures.

3B53A88EA904461384D049B007583320.description:
Make connections between the text of a
story or drama and a visual or oral
presentation of the text, identifying where
each version reflects specific descriptions and
directions in the text.

61204CC3CC184F47A89935342EC77DA5.description:
Compare and contrast the point of view
from which different stories are narrated,
including the difference between first- and
third-person narrations.

8FED8427D0C845F9903B53E81B9E516C.description:
Explain major differences between
poems, drama, and prose, and refer to the
structural elements of poems (e.g., verse,
rhythm, meter) and drama (e.g., casts of
characters, settings, descriptions, dialogue,
stage directions) when writing or speaking
about a text.

3DE7F0F8817549579DB2B3CA47B71639.description:
Determine the meaning of words and
phrases as they are used in a text, including
those that allude to significant characters
found in mythology (e.g., Herculean).

F87F2B756E634F32B4DAB1575F78F9E8.description:
Describe in depth a character, setting, or
event in a story or drama, drawing on specific
details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts,
words, or actions).

726AFCFB140B47539EF14DBECFB163AE.description:
Determine a theme of a story, drama, or
poem from details in the text; summarize the
text.

8782B8B3D275474FA465F257FF68135C.description:
Refer to details and examples in a text
when explaining what the text says explicitly
and when drawing inferences from the text.
